verses.text: But now \add they that are\add* younger than I have me in derision , whose fathers I would have disdained to have set with the dogs of my flock.\f + \fr 30.1 \ft younger…: Heb. of fewer days than I\f*
Yea, whereto \add might\add* the strength of their hands \add profit\add* me, in whom old age was perished ?

For want and famine \add they were\add* solitary ; fleeing into the wilderness in former time desolate and waste.\f + \fr 30.3 \ft solitary: or, dark as the night\f*\f + \fr 30.3 \ft in…: Heb. yesternight\f*
Who cut up mallows by the bushes , and juniper roots \add for\add* their meat.
They were driven forth from among \add men\add*, (they cried after them as \add after\add* a thief ;)
To dwell in the clifts of the valleys , \add in\add* caves of the earth , and \add in\add* the rocks.\f + \fr 30.6 \ft caves: Heb. holes\f*
Among the bushes they brayed ; under the nettles they were gathered together.
\add They were\add* children of fools , yea, children of base men : they were viler than the earth.\f + \fr 30.8 \ft base…: Heb. men of no name\f*
And now am I their song , yea, I am their byword.
They abhor me, they flee far from me, and spare not to spit in my face.\f + \fr 30.10 \ft and…: Heb. and withhold not spittle from\f*
Because he hath loosed my cord , and afflicted me, they have also let loose the bridle before me.
Upon \add my\add* right \add hand\add* rise the youth ; they push away my feet , and they raise up against me the ways of their destruction.
They mar my path , they set forward my calamity , they have no helper.
They came \add upon me\add* as a wide breaking in \add of waters:\add* in the desolation they rolled themselves \add upon me\add*. \p
Terrors are turned upon me: they pursue my soul as the wind : and my welfare passeth away as a cloud.\f + \fr 30.15 \ft my soul: Heb. my principal one\f*
And now my soul is poured out upon me; the days of affliction have taken hold upon me.
My bones are pierced in me in the night season : and my sinews take no rest.
By the great force \add of my disease\add* is my garment changed : it bindeth me about as the collar of my coat.
He hath cast me into the mire , and I am become like dust and ashes.
I cry unto thee, and thou dost not hear me: I stand up , and thou regardest me \add not\add*.
Thou art become cruel to me: with thy strong hand thou opposest thyself against me.\f + \fr 30.21 \ft become…: Heb. turned to be cruel\f*\f + \fr 30.21 \ft thy…: Heb. the strength of thy hand\f*
Thou liftest me up to the wind ; thou causest me to ride \add upon it\add*, and dissolvest my substance.\f + \fr 30.22 \ft substance: or, wisdom\f*
For I know \add that\add* thou wilt bring me \add to\add* death , and \add to\add* the house appointed for all living.
Howbeit he will not stretch out \add his\add* hand to the grave , though they cry in his destruction.\f + \fr 30.24 \ft grave: Heb. heap\f*
Did not I weep for him that was in trouble ? was \add not\add* my soul grieved for the poor ?\f + \fr 30.25 \ft in trouble: Heb. hard of day?\f*
When I looked for good , then evil came \add unto me:\add* and when I waited for light , there came darkness.
My bowels boiled , and rested not: the days of affliction prevented me.
I went mourning without the sun : I stood up , \add and\add* I cried in the congregation.
I am a brother to dragons , and a companion to owls.\f + \fr 30.29 \ft owls: or, ostriches\f*
My skin is black upon me, and my bones are burned with heat.
My harp also is \add turned\add* to mourning , and my organ into the voice of them that weep.
